body:
@erikdubbelboer after https://github.com/druid-io/druid/pull/4116 user can now propagate selected properties to hadoop workers.
Not sure how this was working for you before ?

> Migrate ProtoBuf from v2 to v3

Hi @knoguchi, I wonder how the version migration is done in this patch because it looks like the dependency is actually updated in https://github.com/druid-io/druid/pull/3682. Some users want to know which druid version starts supporting protobuf v3 (https://groups.google.com/forum/?utm_medium=email&utm_source=footer#!msg/druid-user/DaBeEA8Ca50/PXS7l4nUBQAJ).
@himanshug Did you want to review this PR?
:+1:  looked at it today, i think its fine given that @leventov has a real use case for it.
I'll create a backport
ok let me look
Thanks for reviewing @b-slim.
@pjain1 i run `mvn -U dependency:copy-dependencies` from my local machine and it is working fine. Which cache did you deleted ?
I did this - `rm -r ~/.m2/repository/org/apache/ambari` and ran the build locally and the build failed.

@b-slim Should this artifact come from mvn central or hortonworks repo b/c mvn cnetral has this artifact, looks like hortonworks repo is returning 500.

referring to https://github.com/druid-io/druid/blob/ae900a493479bf0be2cef5ce598a6822caa3def1/extensions-contrib/ambari-metrics-emitter/pom.xml#L88

i guess you are right the public one (was using private) is empty repo `http://repo.hortonworks.com/content/repositories/releases/org/apache/ambari/ambari-metrics-common/2.4.1.0.22/`
let me see why the jars is not there.
@pjain1 try now, should be fixed, thanks for reporting.
Thanks for confirming, @erikdubbelboer!
It worked, thanks for the quick fix. Are you guys considering publishing to central maven, might be useful.

Looks like Apache Calcite Avatica introduced by #3682 requires Protobuf3.  I started working on this PR last year Sept or Oct before SQL module was introduced.   Either way, the Protobuf3 com.google.protobuf package is shaded in my extension because Hadoop libraries still depend on Protobuf 2.  Maybe the shading is no longer necessary. 

Out of curiosity I grep'd protobuf-java.  hdfs-storage acually "excluded" protobuf-java.  

```
$ git grep -A2 protobuf-java
extensions-contrib/orc-extensions/pom.xml:                    <artifactId>protobuf-java</artifactId>
extensions-contrib/orc-extensions/pom.xml-                </exclusion>
extensions-contrib/orc-extensions/pom.xml-                <exclusion>
--
extensions-core/druid-kerberos/pom.xml:          <artifactId>protobuf-java</artifactId>
extensions-core/druid-kerberos/pom.xml-        </exclusion>
extensions-core/druid-kerberos/pom.xml-        <exclusion>
--
extensions-core/hdfs-storage/pom.xml:                <artifactId>protobuf-java</artifactId>
extensions-core/hdfs-storage/pom.xml-              </exclusion>
extensions-core/hdfs-storage/pom.xml-              <exclusion>
--
extensions-core/protobuf-extensions/pom.xml:      <artifactId>protobuf-java</artifactId>
extensions-core/protobuf-extensions/pom.xml-      <version>${protobuf.version}</version>
extensions-core/protobuf-extensions/pom.xml-    </dependency>
--
extensions-core/protobuf-extensions/pom.xml:      <artifactId>protobuf-java-util</artifactId>
extensions-core/protobuf-extensions/pom.xml-      <version>${protobuf.version}</version>
extensions-core/protobuf-extensions/pom.xml-    </dependency>
--
pom.xml:                <artifactId>protobuf-java</artifactId>
pom.xml-                <version>3.1.0</version>
pom.xml-            </dependency>
```
Ah, maybe there was a version conflict problem before this patch. Cool. Thank you for the explanation.

@b-slim It seems like this is broken. When I set`tuningConfig.allowedHadoopPrefix` to `[ "druid.storage.", "druid.javascript.", "druid.google." ]` I still get:
```
...
2017-07-13T08:07:10,806 INFO [main] io.druid.indexing.worker.executor.ExecutorLifecycle - Running with task: {
...
      "allowedHadoopPrefix" : [ "druid.storage.", "druid.javascript.", "druid.google." ]
...
2017-07-13T08:07:16,387 INFO [task-runner-0-priority-0] io.druid.indexer.HadoopDruidIndexerConfig - Running with config:
...
      "allowedHadoopPrefix" : [ "druid.storage.", "druid.javascript." ]
...
```
So it doesn't seem to propagate to the actual job.

@b-slim Is it because these methods pass `null` instead of the actual value?: https://github.com/druid-io/druid/blob/3399d1a488896d675e54c1de90a596daea1c045f/indexing-hadoop/src/main/java/io/druid/indexer/HadoopTuningConfig.java#L272-L322

This has fixed the issue for me:
```diff
diff --git a/indexing-hadoop/src/main/java/io/druid/indexer/HadoopTuningConfig.java b/indexing-hadoop/src/main/java/io/druid/indexer/HadoopTuningConfig.java
index e64c0e7..b131a5e 100644
--- a/indexing-hadoop/src/main/java/io/druid/indexer/HadoopTuningConfig.java
+++ b/indexing-hadoop/src/main/java/io/druid/indexer/HadoopTuningConfig.java
@@ -267,7 +267,7 @@ public class HadoopTuningConfig implements TuningConfig
         numBackgroundPersistThreads,
         forceExtendableShardSpecs,
         useExplicitVersion,
-        null
+        allowedHadoopPrefix
     );
   }

@@ -292,7 +292,7 @@ public class HadoopTuningConfig implements TuningConfig
         numBackgroundPersistThreads,
         forceExtendableShardSpecs,
         useExplicitVersion,
-        null
+        allowedHadoopPrefix
     );
   }

@@ -317,7 +317,7 @@ public class HadoopTuningConfig implements TuningConfig
         numBackgroundPersistThreads,
         forceExtendableShardSpecs,
         useExplicitVersion,
-        null
+        allowedHadoopPrefix
     );
   }

```
You want me to make a pull request?
yeah sure will review that, @erikdubbelboer thanks.

How were the properties passed down before? I thought that pre 0.10.1, properties were generally not passed down to the hadoop cluster. So it seems weird that now they'd need to be.

Or is the difference that now in 0.10.1, the druid.storage.type property is passed down, which means now druid.google. needs to be as well if you're using the google extension? If that's the case, I think we should either add druid.google. to the default list, or give the deep storage extensions some way to say what properties they need passed down; otherwise upgrading will be too much of a pain for people using the extension.

@gianm i think you are right, now that we push down the storage properties, guice tries to bind things up, hence the issues. Am not sure what is the best fix but seems like we need to push all the properties of the selected storage module at least. Any way i will send a first PR to fix the null issue (guess @erikdubbelboer is in a different timezone) and then will focus on how to solve this. @gianm should this be part of 0.10.1 ?
@erikdubbelboer thanks for the fix !

@b-slim I think we should at least have something in the release notes explaining the situation. Pushing down the storage properties would be even better. Perhaps we could do this by adding a `getPropertyPrefixForHadoop` to DataSegmentPusher and then automatically adding that prefix to allowedHadoopPrefix for whatever the deep storage is.
Ah, btw, at first I tried with `"mapreduce.job.user.classpath.first": "true"` in the tuningConfig, that didn't work as well

was this working before or it is the first time you run into it ? seems like the jar is not in the class path of the container, am suspecting the class loader isolation is knocking it off the class path.
@jihoonson thanks for review. Could you please merge it?

@b-slim 
Are you planning on working on a fix beyond #4541 for 0.10.1?

If so, let's keep this is 0.10.1 and we can bring the fix into rc2.

If not, let's move this issue to 0.11.0, and I'll mention the storage extension property push in the 0.10.1 release notes.
Sure.
@jihoonson thank you!
@leventov no problem!

donpinkus, you can specify sort order using GroupByQuery's LimitSpec. 

``` 
"limitSpec":{"type":"default","columns":
[{"dimension":"purchase_amount","direction":"descending","dimensionOrder":
{"type":"lexicographic"}}],"limit":2147483647}
```

More details here http://druid.io/docs/latest/querying/limitspec.html

Thanks @b-slim, no, it wasn't working before, I'm just setting it up..
Any idea what to do about this?
i don't want to block the RC for this issue thought, i will get to work on it maybe next week.
@leventov any more comments on this one ?
Updated. Sorry it's a little late.

Just to update this thread that I managed to solve it, pasting the commands that I used, in case it will be helpful to someone... 

1. In Druid middlemgrs/overlord, ran:
```
## build libgplcompression
apt-get install gcc-multilib maven

# lzo
cd /opt
wget http://www.oberhumer.com/opensource/lzo/download/lzo-2.10.tar.gz
tar -zxvf lzo-2.10.tar.gz
cd lzo-2.10/
./configure --enable-shared --prefix /usr/local/lzo-2.06
make
make install

# hadoop lzo
cd /opt
git clone https://github.com/twitter/hadoop-lzo/
cd hadoop-lzo/
C_INCLUDE_PATH=/usr/local/lzo-2.06/include LIBRARY_PATH=/usr/local/lzo-2.06/lib mvn clean package -Dmaven.test.skip=true

## pull hadoop dependencies
java -cp "/opt/druid-0.10.0/lib/*" -Ddruid.extensions.directory="/opt/druid-0.10.0/extensions" -Ddruid.extensions.hadoopDependenciesDir="/opt/druid-0.10.0/hadoop-dependencies" io.druid.cli.Main tools pull-deps --no-default-hadoop -r "http://maven.twttr.com/" -h "org.apache.hadoop:hadoop-client:2.7.3" -h "org.apache.hadoop:hadoop-aws:2.7.3" -h "com.hadoop.gplcompression:hadoop-lzo:0.4.20"
```
2. When running Druid as middlemgr / overlord, add `LD_LIBRARY_PATH=/opt/hadoop-lzo/target/native/Linux-amd64-64/lib/` environment var
3. Set `"hadoopDependencyCoordinates": ["org.apache.hadoop:hadoop-client:2.7.3", "org.apache.hadoop:hadoop-aws:2.7.3", "com.hadoop.gplcompression:hadoop-lzo:0.4.20"]` in the task JSON
4. Set mapreduce.job.classloader=true in mapred-site.xml
@jihoonson could you please merge this PR?
@leventov sorry, i forgot. Merged now.
@jihoonson thanks

I'm trying to post at the [druid-development](https://groups.google.com/forum/?utm_medium=email&utm_source=footer#!msg/druid-development/pSsgt-ugvCM/-rDNNq_7AwAJ) list but my messages keep on being automatically deleted (even without any links).

I don't think this only affects the Google Storage extension. I think it affects all storage extensions as all of them use different prefixes for their properties and all of them inject their config into their SegmentPushers?

> I don't think this only affects the Google Storage extension. I think it affects all storage extensions as all of them use different prefixes for their properties and all of them inject their config into their SegmentPushers?

Most of them put their properties under `druid.storage`, so they aren't affected since the default list does include those. It looks like Google Storage and Azure are the two that don't.

> I'm trying to post at the druid-development list but my messages keep on being automatically deleted (even without any links).

They got stuck in the list's spam filter for some reason. I marked them as not-spam and whitelisted your email address.
Looks like the old messages are deleted though, so you might have to re-post them.

I'm assuming you have this loaded as a string column now, since that's the default for dimensions. A few things could potentially help here.

1. You don't say what kind of filter you're using, but for range and prefix filters on string columns, "bound" and "like" perform substantially better than the alternatives. In your example LIKE "10.0.0%" should work best. For running these on IPs, it can help to store them in 0-padded hex encoding rather than dotted decimal, since that will make any subnet range or prefix search doable with a "bound" or "like" filter.
2. Roaring bitmaps tend to work better than Concise for unioning large numbers of bitmaps, so you could try switching to those (at indexing time using `"indexSpec" : { "bitmap" : { "type" : "roaring" } }` in your tuningConfig).
3. If you don't have any IPv6, you can also try loading the IP column as a "long" rather than the default of "string". Longs are currently unindexed in Druid, which may or may not hurt depending on your queries. So they tend to be faster sometimes and slower sometimes depending on your query. If you have IPv6 then this isn't doable since we don't have a numeric type that wide.
At the moment I only have a thetasketch of the IP to count them. To be able to filter on IP is a new requirement and Im looking into what options there are.

Ah okay. Well, in that case, try doing either a "string" or "long" dimension. One of them should work best for you. On strings, make sure to use "selector", "bound", and "like" filters if possible. They're the fastest. On longs, "selector" and "bound" are fastest.

I don't think you can do it with information stored in thetaSketch which is just maintaining hashes to do unique counts.
this would definitely require storing IPs into a dimension column and using the inbuilt selector/bound etc filters.
@leventov @jon-wei  TeamCity build failed in this PR , I looked at the logs and errors did not look related to updates made in this PR. Is that expected to fail for now ?
I've noticed similar issues on other patches (teamcity failing on files unrelated to the patch). It seems flaky for some reason.
ok, backporting it to 0.10.1 now

I guess if you want to store your segments in S3 you also need druid.s3: https://github.com/druid-io/druid/blob/60cdf946778d0624db6ddce0366e5fdb131437b2/extensions-core/s3-extensions/src/main/java/io/druid/storage/s3/S3StorageDruidModule.java#L77

I think S3 should be ok, since Hadoop's S3 FileSystem is used for connection from hadoop -> s3, not Druid's S3 client. So even though Druid's S3 client won't be properly instantiated, it wouldn't matter.

Has anyone tried this with 0.10.1-rc1 to confirm? I _think_ we have but I'm not totally sure.
@gianm We did run some hadoop tests against 0.10.1 before rc1 was released for this PR: https://github.com/druid-io/druid/pull/4116, but the deep storage was HDFS in those tests.
@leventov thanks i have addressed the last comments.
I just ran a batch ingestion task with 0.10.1-rc1 with EMR, using S3 as deep storage, the task worked
There's a checkstyle error in Travis
Fixed by #4360.
@erikdubbelboer could you try #4562 to see if that works for you, without having to specify allowedHadoopPrefix in the task?
+1 after travis
My PR failed on tests: io.druid.query.lookup.TestKafkaExtractionCluster due to "Interrupted Controller took to long to awaken". @leventov could you restart the build ?
@michalmisiewicz please fix the rest two formatting issues
@michalmisiewicz thanks. Unless somebody else comes with review comments, I'll merge this PR in a couple of days
@gianm thanks !

@leventov By removing the else condition here https://github.com/druid-io/druid/pull/4472/files#diff-1e2aafb09822d416037bbcc45f163303L201, there are segments in the currentlyMovingSegments list which will never be removed. If they are not removed, then the coordinator will never assign new segments because of this https://github.com/druid-io/druid/blob/master/server/src/main/java/io/druid/server/coordinator/helper/DruidCoordinatorBalancer.java#L99-L103 ?

Am I missing something?

@leventov The callbacks that you pointed out are only registered for segments which match https://github.com/druid-io/druid/blob/master/server/src/main/java/io/druid/server/coordinator/helper/DruidCoordinatorBalancer.java#L170-L172 . 
For those that are in "else" have to be removed, and in the PR code that "else statement" has been removed

> ""Also I'm not sure that it's actually bad if currentlyMovingSegments never becomes empty (because there are always more segments to move). It won't "reduce lifetimes" (I don't really understand what does it mean), but is that bad?""

That is not bad, it just means that it will take more cycles to process the segments and no new assignments will be done till they are removed. Which is alright.
@leventov thanks done.
is https://github.com/druid-io/druid/blob/master/druid_intellij_formatting.xml up-to-date to format code that would be compliant to the rules introduced ?
@himanshug yes
If it is tested and it works fine, then 👍

@leventov @dgolitsyn This change looks good 👍 . We have seen this happen when we use `DiskNormalizedCostBalancerStrategy.java` and add new boxes to our cluster. 

It would be great if you could deploy this new cost function and ensure that it is not worse off.
@leventov done
@leventov thanks for reviewing this !

@pjain1 @himanshug @nishantmonu51 @jihoonson 

This patch is now ready for review, can you all please take a look when you have a chance?

This PR contains the new interfaces and some refactoring, an example implementation of these new interfaces can be found here:

https://github.com/jon-wei/druid/pull/1
@leventov @akashdw thanks for looking at the first patch. It's now ready for review.
had no effect, closing

This PR should unblock the Travis CI failures occurring today.

I think we could merge this to unblock PR acceptance for now and get the tests working with Travis's Trusty image in a later PR.

@gianm I looks like #4562 can't be applied to the 0.10.1 branch we are running. I tried upgrading only our middlemanager node to master but this just resulted in lots of `java.io.IOException: Failed to locate service uri` exceptions when starting a task. Do you have any suggestion on how to test this without having to upgrade our whole cluster to master?

@erikdubbelboer please try https://github.com/druid-io/druid/pull/4567 which is a backport of that to 0.10.1.

Although, exceptions when middleManagers are upgraded and the rest of the cluster is not, are concerning since we do want to support upgrading them first as part of a rolling update. Could you please paste the full error message & stack traces you got when you saw those errors? Might be something we need to fix.

Unclear what you are asking. What do you mean by "bitmap expand too much"? "columns in a segment are integers" -- you mean integer (actually long, because Druid doesn't have 4-byte integer dimensions now) dimensions or metrics? "bitmap size maybe equal to the actual datasize" what is "bitmap size" and "datasize" here?
@jon-wei nice work! Would you check the travis failure? I'll review tomorrow.

Hmm, in SQL the supported orderings are "as string" and "as number". You can switch which one you get by using the CAST operator. But there isn't one that works well for version numbers.

You could probably write a SqlOperatorConversion that creates a new function that transforms version numbers into something that sorts properly as a string or a number, and then do order by that. Something like `SELECT DISTINCT version FROM tbl ORDER BY VERSION_SORTABLE(version)` where `VERSION_SORTABLE` is an operator you add in an extension. Maybe it transforms "9.0.0.1" to "0009.0000.0000.0001".

Alternatively you could teach the SQL dialect about a new kind of ordering, but that can't be done through an extension, it would have to be done by a patch to druid-sql module itself.

Additionally, in my situation, I need to use version comparison with bound filters, such as `SELECT DISTINCT version FROM tbl WHERE version >= '9.0.0.1' and version <= '10.1.0.0'`. 

Maybe I could write a SqlOperatorConversion and use the custom function like  `SELECT DISTINCT version FROM tbl WHERE VERSION_SORTABLE(version) >= VERSION_SORTABLE('9.0.0.1') and VERSION_SORTABLE(version) <= VERSION_SORTABLE('10.1.0.0')`?

If I do things like this,  what impact will be on performance?
This patch is a great step forwards, but it broke a lot of Druid SQL stuff. Please, consider Druid SQL when reviewing design of PRs. I will try to fix the problems before 0.11.0 is released.

That'd work. The impact on performance for the filtering would be that the VERSION_SORTABLE function will be applied to each distinct version number at query time (since this would likely get planned be an index based filter). If it's fast enough that should be ok.
@gianm not sure what is exactly broken all the UTs are passing including the SQL one. I can help fixing stuff if it is clear what is broken.
Sorry, I'm wrong, it looks like the UTs do test double columns. But they're not testing float columns, and there's still some wires crossed where it treats doubles as floats. I'll take a closer look…
